title: Chemical Storage and Handling in Harvest Areas
description: Requirements for secure chemical storage, proper labeling, separation from product areas, spill prevention, and safe handling procedures in harvest operations

requirements.question: Are chemicals, including pesticides and cleaning agents, stored away from harvest and product handling areas?
requirements.automaticFailureReason: Chemicals stored in harvest areas pose direct contamination risk and potential for product adulteration.

requirements.question: Are fuel containers, including gasoline and diesel, stored away from product and product contact surfaces?
When chemicals must be present in harvest areas, are they properly labeled and secured?
Are workers trained on the proper handling and storage of any chemicals present during harvest operations?
Are there procedures to prevent cross-contamination between chemicals and harvested product?

mandatoryStatements: Chemicals including pesticides, cleaning agents, and fertilizers must be stored away from harvest areas and product handling zones.
Fuel containers (gasoline, diesel, lubricants) must be stored and handled to prevent contamination of product or product contact surfaces.
When chemicals are necessarily present in harvest areas (e.g., sanitizers, equipment fuel), they must be properly labeled, secured, and separated from product.
Workers who handle or may come in contact with chemicals during harvest operations must receive appropriate training.
Procedures must be in place to prevent cross-contamination between chemicals and harvested product through separate storage, equipment, and handling.
capaInject: Designate specific chemical storage areas well away from harvest operations with appropriate containment, ventilation, and security measures.
Establish protocols for any chemicals that must temporarily enter harvest areas including authorization, containment, labeling, and supervision requirements.
Implement color-coding or clear labeling systems to prevent confusion between chemical containers and food-safe containers or equipment.
Develop spill response procedures specific to chemical releases in or near harvest areas including product hold, cleanup, and clearance protocols.
Create inspection checklists for supervisors to verify proper chemical storage and handling compliance during harvest operations.
traceabilityInject: Maintain inventory records of all chemicals present on-site including storage locations, quantities, and dates.
Document worker training on chemical handling including specific products, hazards, safe handling procedures, and emergency response.
Keep records of any chemical applications made in or near harvest areas including product name, rate, date, applicator, and re-entry interval.
Log any chemical spills or incidents in harvest areas including product affected, corrective actions, and disposition of potentially contaminated product.
Track movement of fuel and chemical containers with sign-out/sign-in procedures when they must enter harvest zones temporarily.
micro_inject: Ensure workers understand that even small amounts of chemical residue can contaminate large volumes of product and create health hazards.
Verify that sanitizers and cleaning chemicals used near product are food-grade and approved for such use to minimize contamination risk.
Implement protocols to prevent chemical containers or equipment from serving as vectors for pathogen transfer if contaminated with soil or organic matter.
Monitor that fuel storage and handling does not create conditions favorable for microbial growth through spills or contamination of water sources.
Verify proper hand hygiene after any chemical handling to prevent transfer of chemicals or associated contamination to product surfaces.
